body:
I have several questions for this issue:
- Do we want to run the tasks on a separate server?
- Do we want/need to provision a separate infrastructure for worker computing? If so, do we already have plan about auto-scaling?
- If yes, do we need advanced features like monitoring, auto-retry and stuff like that?
- Where is the service gonna run? We spoke about Heroku and Mozilla infrastructure, the choice will be impacted by where it should run.
- Do we have an idea how big the batch will be? 10s, 100s, 1000s or more?

> Do we want to run the tasks on a separate server?

Probably the same server, with a background worker.

> Do we want/need to provision a separate infrastructure for worker computing? If so, do we already have plan about auto-scaling?

I think the same infra that will run the http service will also run the worker in the background. No plans about auto-scaling, but I wouldn't expect this to be a problem any time soon.

> If yes, do we need advanced features like monitoring, auto-retry and stuff like that?

I don't think so, at least for now. The main source of failure will be the connection to Bugzilla for retrieving bugs, but simple retry should be enough.

> Where is the service gonna run? We spoke about Heroku and Mozilla infrastructure, the choice will be impacted by where it should run.

Either Heroku or AWS directly.
At some point we might leave the deployment part to Mozilla's cloudops team, but it's very similar to Heroku as long as you have a Docker image that they can run.

> Do we have an idea how big the batch will be? 10s, 100s, 1000s or more?

Probably 100s up to 1000s. We should have some caching so that some results can be retrieved very quickly without actually running the model.

I think row-oriented one is nicer. We could also make it a list instead of a map, as you prefer.

E.g.:
```
[
    {
        'bugid': 123456,
        'probs': [...],
        'index': 1,
        'result': 'Component',
    },
]
```
I prefer the map as it allows direct access to the result for a given bugid while the list forces the consumer to filter the list or consume the list entirely.
This should have been fixed by #321, we just need to confirm after the next http service deployment.
This is good for me, @marco-c I let you close this issue
